justification: Systemic mastocytosis is a rare disorder characterized by the accumulation of mast cells in various tissues, leading to a variety of symptoms, including abdominal cramps, diarrhea, hives, angioedema, and in some cases, incontinence.}, {diagnosis: Anaphylaxis

justification: Anaphylaxis is a severe allergic reaction that can cause hives, angioedema, abdominal cramps, diarrhea, and in some cases, loss of bladder control (incontinence).}, {diagnosis: Food allergy

justification: Food allergies can cause a range of symptoms, from mild to severe. In some cases, they can trigger hives, angioedema, abdominal cramps, diarrhea, and even incontinence.}, {diagnosis: Medication allergy

justification: Like food allergies, medication allergies can also cause a variety of symptoms, including hives, angioedema, abdominal cramps, diarrhea, and potentially incontinence.}, {diagnosis: Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD)

justification: IBD, encompassing conditions like Crohns disease and ulcerative colitis, can cause persistent diarrhea, abdominal cramps, and in some cases, incontinence. While less common, IBD can also be associated with hives and angioedema.}, {diagnosis: Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS)

justification: IBS is a common disorder that affects the large intestine. It can cause abdominal cramps, diarrhea, and incontinence. While not directly causing hives or angioedema, IBS can sometimes worsen alongside allergic reactions.}, {diagnosis: Carcinoid syndrome

justification: Carcinoid syndrome is a rare disorder caused by tumors that release hormones. It can cause diarrhea, abdominal cramps, and flushing, which might be mistaken for hives. Angioedema and incontinence are less common but possible.}, {diagnosis: Acute gastroenteritis (Stomach flu)

justification: Viral or bacterial gastroenteritis can cause abdominal cramps, diarrhea, and sometimes incontinence due to severe dehydration. While hives and angioedema are less common, they can occur in some cases.}, {diagnosis: Pelvic floor dysfunction

justification: Pelvic floor dysfunction primarily causes incontinence but can also lead to abdominal pain and discomfort, sometimes perceived as cramps. Its not associated with hives, angioedema, or diarrhea.}, {diagnosis: Anxiety or panic disorder

justification: Severe anxiety or panic attacks can cause a wide range of physical symptoms, including abdominal cramps, diarrhea, and even incontinence. While not directly causing hives or angioedema, anxiety can sometimes worsen alongside allergic reactions.}
